description: From East Anglian dialectal English cliver (“expert at seizing”), from Middle English cliver (“tenacious”), perhaps from Old English *clifer, clibbor (“clinging”), or perhaps from East Frisian (compare Saterland Frisian kluftich), or dialectal Norwegian klover (“ready, skillful”); possibly influenced by Old English clifer (“claw, hand”). Related to cleave. Perhaps influenced by Welsh celfydd (“talented, dexterous, expert”).

adjectives.description: clever (comparative cleverer or more clever, superlative cleverest or most clever)

entries.meaning: Nimble with hands or body; skillful; adept.
examples: The Highland men, they're clever men  At handling sword and shield,

entries.meaning: Quick to understand, learn, and devise or apply ideas; intelligent.

examples: A simple but clever trick to solve the problem.

entries.meaning: Skilled at achieving what one wants, especially via unusual methods.
examples: With a clever lawyer, she could easily be acquitted.

entries.meaning: Smart, intelligent, or witty; mentally quick or sharp.
examples: Be good, sweet maid, and let who will be clever;  Do noble things, not dream them all day long:  And so make life, death, and that vast forever / One grand, sweet song.

entries.meaning: (of objects or actions) Showing inventiveness or originality; witty.
(anthropology, of an Aboriginal Australian) Possessing magical abilities.
examples: When a clever man is out hunting and comes across the tracks of, say, a kangaroo, he follows them along and talks to the footprints all the time for the purpose of injecting magic into the animal which made them.
I can't but think 'twould sound more clever,  To me and to my heirs forever.

entries.meaning: (UK, colloquial) Fit and healthy; free from fatigue or illness.
